Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Ecosystem Design Tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is to enable tools to inform methods to reduce air pollution. Air pollution increases the risk of cancer, stroke, heart disease, respiratory infections; further, it may play a role in Alzheimer's disease and diabetes, resulting in trillions of dollars of health care costs globally each year. Half of these costs may be attributed to roadway traffic sourced pollution. Traffic sourced pollution is possibly intercepted by trees, although improperly configured roadside trees do not produce these benefits and creating the opportunity for improved health via targeted engineering of roadside tree placements. This project will develop analysis and design tools to make sure that such tree plantings optimize benefits for ecosystem designers, health insurance companies, governments, and local businesses.

This SBIR project will develop a system to optimize high-resolution site-specific tree placement for pollution reduction. Trees are known to reduce air pollution by acting like filters as their high surface area attracts pollutants. Tightly packed trees of a type with high surface area placed on the leeward side of a busy roadway can intercept > 30% of traffic sourced pollutants. This project will perform ground-based, high-resolution vegetation analysis on neighborhoods under study. These data will be used to train an algorithm to infer high-resolution vegetation properties from widely available, low-cost data streams. These inferred vegetation metrics will be integrated with a geospatial ecosystem design automation pipeline to create a software tool. To accurately predict the capture, high-resolution vegetation surface area measurements, tree crown spacing information, wind speed, wind direction and roadway traffic volumes will be aggregated in a comprehensive model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Air pollution from traffic increases the risk of cancer, stroke, heart-disease, respiratory infections, and may play a role in Alzhiemer’s disease and diabetes, resulting in trillions of dollars in annual health care costs worldwide. Studies on carefully placed roadside vegetation have indicated that such traffic-sourced pollution can be intercepted by well located trees, although improperly configured roadside trees do not produce these benefits. This suggests that there is a potential mechanism for improving human health via targeted engineering of roadside tree placements. 

Trees reduce air pollution by acting like filters, their high surface area causes pollution to stick to them. Trees that are closer to pollution sources (like busy roadways) will capture more pollution than trees far from the source, as will trees with higher surface area. In order to maximize the benefits of targeted roadside tree planting, a comprehensive model built from high resolution vegetation surface area measurements, tree crown spacing information, wind speed, wind direction and roadway traffic volumes is required.

    For this project we built a prototype and a tool to use the data to aid in the design of effective ecosystem interventions. The tool provides localized high resolution roadside vegetation surface-area estimates, along with estimates of which land areas are available for planting. These estimates are generated using the cutting-edge machine learning framework developed during this project.

    To create the high resolution roadside vegetation surface area estimator, we measured the surface area of thousands of trees, photographed them, and then trained a machine learning system to estimate surface area from the photos. Now our tool can download street-view photos from any area where such photos are available, and get high resolution surface area estimates for roadside vegetation. We built an automated system for obtaining the street-view images, using them to estimate vegetation surface area, and serve the data to a user in a geographic interface. The geographic interface also includes wind and traffic data that we obtain from public sources and serve from our databases. All of these site analytics can be used to inform the design of the most effective interventions for minimizing the impact of air pollution on health. 

    By reducing the costs of high definition ecosystem measurement, we have opened the doors to wide-scale adoption of evidence-based environmental health projects. As these new analytical technologies are incorporated into studies on the health impacts of ecosystem services, they will not only provide more detailed insights into the mechanisms of impact, but will also guide people to effectively improve the environment for the benefit of all. 

Prior to this project, measuring the surface area of vegetation at a spatial resolution relevant to near-road traffic pollution impacts was only possible at a small scale, for example by collecting leaves by hand or using a stationary LIDAR scanner that can cover less than a city-block per hour. By adapting these methods to work for street-view photographs that can be acquired from numerous sources for almost any location with roads, we have expanded the domain of such high resolution data to a global scale at a fraction of the cost.

In addition to the impact of the above analytical technologies, the automated design components of our tool impact the ability of health stakeholders to take meaningful action to improve community health based on the information provided by the analytical engine. The tools developed in this project will automate and optimize the design process in a continuously improving manner based on feedback from real air monitoring projects and cutting edge modeling. 

In the process of developing these technologies, we have also gathered a huge amount of data in multiple neighborhoods that are the subject of ongoing clinical studies on the health impacts of near-road vegetation. This data may impact the outcomes of those studies by providing much higher resolution vegetation surface area information than would otherwise be available, as well as additional metrics of relevance such as the proportion of human-occupied areas exposed to trees, the sky, roads, trucks, buildings and many other quantified aspects of the local environment. 

The impact of the resulting health research will be the enabling of health insurance companies, governments, and other health stakeholders to financially justify spending money to improve the environment by planting trees and defragmenting biodiversity. While many people recognize intuitively that such activities would benefit people’s health, and there is much observational evidence that they do, the technologies developed in this project will help bring that evidence to the level required for large economic actors to treat nature like a life-saving medicine or critical life-support infrastructure, rather than a nice-to-have extractive resource.
